form.preferredDefinition: Measurement of respondent's symptoms of cigarette dependence.

question.questionText: CURRENT SMOKER?
Was there a 6month period when you smoked more than you do now?
Current EveryDay or Current SomeDay Smokers How soon after you wake up do/did you smoke your first cigarette?
Current EveryDay or Current SomeDay Smokers Do/Did you find it difficult to refrain from smoking in places where it is forbidden, e.g., in church, at the library, in a cinema, etc.?
Current EveryDay or Current SomeDay Smokers Which cigarette would you hate most to give up?

validValue.meaningText: The first one in the morning [1 point]

question.questionText: Current EveryDay or Current SomeDay Smokers How many cigarettes per day do/did you smoke?
Current EveryDay or Current SomeDay Smokers Do/did you smoke more frequently during the first hours after waking than during the rest of the day?
Current EveryDay or Current SomeDay Smokers Do/did you smoke if you are so ill that you are in bed most of the day?
Former Smokers How soon after you wake up do/did you smoke your first cigarette?
Former Smokers Do/Did you find it difficult to refrain from smoking in places where it is forbidden, e.g., in church, at the library, in a cinema, etc.?
Former Smokers Which cigarette would you hate most to give up?

validValue.meaningText: The first one in the morning [1 point]

question.questionText: Former Smokers How many cigarettes per day do/did you smoke?
Former Smokers Do/did you smoke more frequently during the first hours after waking than during the rest of the day?
Former Smokers Do/did you smoke if you are so ill that you are in bed most of the day?

protocol.preferredDefinition: Measurement of respondent's symptoms of cigarette dependence.

form.preferredDefinition: Measurement of respondent's lifetime use of illicit and prescribed substances.

question.questionText: Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Sedatives, for example, sleeping pills, barbiturates, Seconal, Quaaludes, or Chloral Hydrate Specify
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Tranquilizers or antianxiety drugs, for example, Valium, Librium, muscle relaxants, or Zanax Specify
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Painkillers, for example, Codeine, Darvon, Percodan, Oxycontin, Dilaudid, Demerol, Celebrex, or Vioxx Specify
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Stimulants, for example, Preludin, Benzedrine, Methedrine, Ritalin, uppers, or speed Specify
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Marijuana, hash, THC, or grass Specify
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Cocaine or crack Specify
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Hallucinogens, for example, Ecstasy/MDMA, LSD, mescaline, psilocybin, PCP, angel dust, or peyote Specify
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Inhalants or solvents, for example, amyl nitrite, nitrous oxide, glue, toluene or gasoline Specify
Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Heroin

Have you EVER used any of these medicines or drugs? Any OTHER medicines, or drugs, or substances, for example, methadone, Elavil, steroids, Thorazine or Haldol? (SELECT MOST FREQUENTLY USED OTHER DRUG)

protocol.preferredDefinition: Measurement of respondent's lifetime use of illicit and prescribed substances.

form.longName: PhenX Family History Of Heart Attack - PX040101
form.preferredDefinition: This measure assesses if the respondent's biological parents, siblings, and children have had a heart attack.

question.questionText: Did your mother, father, fullblooded sisters, fullblooded brothers, daughters, or sons ever have a heart attack or myocardial infarction?

For these questions, please think about fullblooded relatives only. Do not think about halfsisters or halfbrothers, or relatives who are related to you by marriage or adoption. Fullblooded sisters and brothers are those who had the same two parents as you. If you are adopted or are not sure about some relatives' health history, please include any family history that you know about.
Did your mom, dad, siblings, kids have heart attack?
Did your mother have a heart attack?

Yes. 65 or older when the first heart attack occurred

Don't know if she had a heart attack

form.preferredDefinition: Measure of plasma lipid levels in blood samples to predict risk for the development of heart attack or to define metabolic syndrome.

question.questionText: If the respondent answers "yes" to question 1, then the interviewer will proceed to question 2. The use of lipidlowering medications must be captured, as the use of medications can have profound and predictable effects on the lipid levels and obscure the levels and phenotype of hyperlipidemia. Lipid profiles involving triglyceridelevel measurement should be collected after an 812 hour fast. Generally, total cholesterol, highdensity lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, and triglycerides should be measured in a laboratory that is certified and referenced to a regional reference laboratory.
Has a doctor or nurse ever said that you have high blood cholesterol?
Have you ever taken medication for high blood cholesterol?
At what age did you begin taking medicine for this?
At what age did you begin taking medicine for this?
Interview: Was blood requested for lipid profile?
Interview: Was consent given?
Interview: Was blood drawn successfully?
Date blood drawn for lipid profile (mm/dd/yyyy)
Time blood drawn for lipid profile (hh:mm am/pm)
Total cholesterol from lipid profile
LDL from lipid profile
HDL from lipid profile
Triglycerides from lipid profile

protocol.preferredDefinition: Measure of plasma lipid levels in blood samples to predict risk for the development of heart attack or to define metabolic syndrome.

At what age were you first told this?
FOR WOMEN: Was this during pregnancy only?
Have you ever taken medication for hypertension/high blood pressure?
At what age did you begin taking medicine for this?
At what age did you begin taking medicine for this?

Did you have (Have you had) any of these illnesses or complications during this pregnancy? High blood pressure without toxemia?

form.preferredDefinition: This measure assesses if a patient died of sudden cardiac arrest by reviewing symptoms prior to death, timing of death, possible cardiac origin via autopsy evidence, and/or demonstration of a history of cardiac disease via physician questionnaire and medical records review.

question.questionText: To be completed by physician who signed the death certificate and/or the patient's physician.
Are you familiar with the events surrounding the decedent's death?
Did you witness the death?
Was there any pain in the chest, left arm or shoulder or jaw within 72 hours of death?
Did the pain include the chest?
Did you think this pain was of a cardiac origin?
Did you think this pain was of a cardiac origin? If no, specify what you think was the cause.
Was cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and/or cardioversion performed within 24 hours of death?
Please give time between onset of acute symptoms to death. (We are defining death as the point where spontaneous breathing ceased and the patient never recovered).

validValue.meaningText: At least 12 hours, but less than 24 hours
At least 4 hours, but less than 12 hours
At least 1 hour, but less than 4 hours

question.questionText: Would you classify the decedent's cause of death as due to Coronary Heart Disease (CHD)?
Location of death

validValue.meaningText: Emergency Room (not dead on arrival- DOA)
Nursing Home, Skilled Nursing Facility (SNF), or Extended Care Facility (ECF)

question.questionText: Location of death
Was the death witnessed?
MultiEthnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) classification of underlying cause of death (choose one)

validValue.meaningText: Atherosclerotic disease other than coronary disease or stroke
Other cardiovascular disease, not defined above

question.questionText: MultiEthnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) classification of underlying cause of death: Atherosclerotic disease other than coronary disease or stroke (specify)
MultiEthnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) classification of underlying cause of death: Other cardiovascular disease, not defined above (specify)
MultiEthnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) classification of underlying cause of death: Noncardiovascular disease (specify)
Type of fatal coronary heart disease.

validValue.meaningText: Definite fatal myocardial infarction (MI) (no known non-atherosclerotic cause and definite myocardial infarction within 4 weeks of death)
Definite fatal coronary heart disease (CHD) (no known non-atherosclerotic cause, and one or both of the following: chest pain within 72 hours of death or a history of chronic ischemic heart disease)
Possible fatal coronary heart disease (CHD) (no known non-atherosclerotic cause, and death certificate underlying cause: I20-25, I46, I51.6, R96 or R98-99)

question.questionText: Estimated time between onset of acute cardiac symptoms and death.
Mechanism of death in patients dying of cardiovascular causes (check all that apply).

validValue.meaningText: Cardiac procedure such as coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) or angioplasty

question.questionText: Mechanism of death in patients dying of cardiovascular causes

protocol.preferredDefinition: This measure assesses if a patient died of sudden cardiac arrest by reviewing symptoms prior to death, timing of death, possible cardiac origin via autopsy evidence, and/or demonstration of a history of cardiac disease via physician questionnaire and medical records review.

form.preferredDefinition: This measure assesses if an individual has had a myocardial infarction (MI) through collection of personal history of disease, treatment and procedure histories, and medical record abstraction.

question.questionText: Has a doctor ever told you that you had a myocardial infarction or heart attack?
Have you had an outpatient or day surgery procedure to unblock blocked or narrowed blood vessels of the heart (called a PTCA, coronary angioplasty, stent, or atherectomy)?
Was there an acute episode of pain, discomfort or tightness in the chest, left arm or jaw within 72 hours of the hospitalization or within 72 hours of the inhospital event?
Was the discomfort or pain diagnosed as having a noncardiac origin?
Were electrocardiograms (ECGs or EKGs) recorded?
Dates of ECGs image
Were any cardiac enzyme measurements performed during this admission?
Did the participant have any active liver disease (cirrhosis, hepatitis, liver cancer, etc.)?
Did the participant have any active liver disease (cirrhosis, hepatitis, liver cancer, etc.)? If Yes specify.
Is there any mention of the participant having either trauma, a surgical procedure, or rhabdomyolysis within one week prior to the measurement of the cardiac enzymes?

Is there any mention of the participant having either trauma, a surgical procedure, or rhabdomyolysis within one week prior to the measurement of the cardiac enzymes? If Yes specify type of trauma or procedure.
Enzyme Chart image
Enzyme Chart image 2
Record all serum enzyme values Serum enzyme
Record all serum enzyme values Normal Range
Record all serum enzyme values Lowest enzyme value
Record all serum enzyme values Highest enzyme value
Record all serum enzyme values Date (mm/dd/yy)
Record all serum enzyme values Time (hh:mm am/pm)
Myocardial infarction
Myocardial infarction Date
Chest Pain
Cardiac Enzymes
ECG Serial Reading (pick one)

validValue.meaningText: Evolution of ST-T Elevation with or without Q-Wave
Single ECG with LBBB, described as new

question.questionText: Procedurerelated

protocol.preferredDefinition: This measure assesses if an individual has had a myocardial infarction (MI) through collection of personal history of disease, treatment and procedure histories, and medical record abstraction.

form.preferredDefinition: This measure begins with a set of interviewer-administered questions about whether the person has been told by a physician that he or she has poor blood flow to the legs or blocked or narrowed arteries to the legs and whether they have had any procedures, such as angiography, angioplasty, or surgery, for the condition. A protocol is provided to assess the presence of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) using the ankle brachial index (ABI). The ABI involves the use of ultrasound to measure blood pressure.

question.questionText: Did a doctor ever say that you had claudication or peripheral arterial disease (poor blood flow to the legs or blocked or narrowed arteries to the legs)? Do not include varicose veins or phlebitis.
For the above condition have you ever had... Angiography (dye in the arteries of the legs)?
For the above condition have you ever had... Angioplasty (balloon catheter to open blockage)?
For the above condition have you ever had... Surgery to improve blood flow in your legs (do not include surgery for varicose veins)?
Blood pressure measurement, sphygmomanometer name and model.
Blood pressure measurement, cuff size for arm.
Blood pressure measurement, cuff size for ankle.
Arterial Blood Pressure Measurement. Measure systolic blood pressure of: Right brachial artery (Q1a) (mm Hg).
Arterial Blood Pressure Measurement. Measure systolic blood pressure of: Right dorsalis pedis artery (Q1b)
Arterial Blood Pressure Measurement. Measure systolic blood pressure of: Right posterior tibial artery (Q1c) (mm Hg).
Arterial Blood Pressure Measurement. Measure systolic blood pressure of: Left posterior tibial artery (Q1d) (mm Hg).
Arterial Blood Pressure Measurement. Measure systolic blood pressure of: Left dorsalis pedis artery (Q1e) (mm Hg).
Arterial Blood Pressure Measurement. Measure systolic blood pressure of: Left brachial artery (Q1f) (mm Hg).
Right ABI = (the higher of the right posterior tibial SBP or the right dorsalis pedis SBP) / (the higher arm SBP)
LEFT ABI = (the higher of the left posterior tibial SBP or the left dorsalis pedis SBP) / (the higher arm SBP)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This measure begins with a set of interviewer-administered questions about whether the person has been told by a physician that he or she has poor blood flow to the legs or blocked or narrowed arteries to the legs and whether they have had any procedures, such as angiography, angioplasty, or surgery, for the condition. A protocol is provided to assess the presence of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) using the ankle brachial index (ABI). The ABI involves the use of ultrasound to measure blood pressure.

form.preferredDefinition: A screening question is asked about whether a person has been told that they have deep venous thrombosis (DVT) or blood clots in their legs. If the response is "yes," then two questions are asked about treatment for the condition. The third protocol provides a method to improve documentation of the condition by abstracting additional information from the person's medical record about the history and laboratory findings of DVT.

question.questionText: Has a doctor ever told you that you had deep venous thrombosis or blood clots in your legs?

Have you ever been treated by a doctor or a nurse with shots at home or as an outpatient (usually followed by blood thinning medications such as Coumadin, Warfarin) for blood clots in the legs called deep vein thrombosis or DVT?
Have you ever had outpatient test(s) performed for blood clots in the legs called deep vein thrombosis or DVT?

Complete the following for all hospitalized pulmonary embolism (PE)/deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Complete the following if outpatient (OP) records confirm deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or an autopsy report confirms pulmonary embolism.
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
Date of Diagnosis (mm/dd/yyyy).
Diagnosis: (Mark the one category that applies best.)

validValue.meaningText: Deep vein thrombosis of lower extremities not resulting from a procedure within 60 days
Deep vein thrombosis of lower extremities during or following a procedure within 60 days

question.questionText: Diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis is based on: (Mark all that apply.)

validValue.meaningText: Hospital discharge summary with a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis
Positive findings on doppler duplex, ultrasound, sonogram, or other non-invasive test examination

question.questionText: Diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis reporting source: (Mark one. If more than one category applies, mark the first applicable category.)

protocol.preferredDefinition: A screening question is asked about whether a person has been told that they have deep venous thrombosis (DVT) or blood clots in their legs. If the response is "yes," then two questions are asked about treatment for the condition. The third protocol provides a method to improve documentation of the condition by abstracting additional information from the person's medical record about the history and laboratory findings of DVT.

form.preferredDefinition: A screening question is asked about whether a person has been told that they have pulmonary embolus or blood clots. If the response is yes, then the second protocol provides a method for abstracting additional information from the person's medical record about the history of pulmonary embolism.

question.questionText: Has a doctor ever told you that you had pulmonary embolus or blood clots in your lungs?

Complete the following for all hospitalized pulmonary embolism (PE)/deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Complete the following if outpatient (OP) records confirm deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or an autopsy report confirms pulmonary embolism.
Pulmonary embolism (PE) requiring hospitalization:
Date of Diagnosis: (mm/dd/yyyy)
Diagnosis: (Mark the one category that applies best.)

validValue.meaningText: Pulmonary embolism not resulting from a procedure within 60 days
Pulmonary embolism during or following a procedure within 60 days

question.questionText: Diagnosis of pulmonary embolism is based on: (Mark all that apply.)

validValue.meaningText: Hospital discharge summary with a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism
High probability on ventilation-perfusion lung scan (exclude moderate, intermediate, or low probability on ventilation-perfusion lung scan)
Positive findings on pulmonary angiogram or spiral CAT scan (CT)

Diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) based on ? 1 deep vein thrombosis (DVT) criteria in question 1.3 (link to Form 126 in Source section below) plus signs and symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolism (PE) (e.g., acute chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia, tachycardia, or chest x-ray findings suggestive of pulmonary embolism)

protocol.preferredDefinition: A screening question is asked about whether a person has been told that they have pulmonary embolus or blood clots. If the response is yes, then the second protocol provides a method for abstracting additional information from the person's medical record about the history of pulmonary embolism.

form.longName: PhenX Rheumatic Fever Rheumatic Heart Disease - PX041401

form.preferredDefinition: These interviewer-administered questions ascertain whether an infant was breastfed, the duration of breastfeeding, and the introduction of solid foods.

question.questionText: Was Sample Person ever breastfed or fed breast milk?
How old was Sample Person when {he/she} was first fed something other than breastmilk or water?
How old was Sample Person when {he/she} was first fed something other than breastmilk or water? INCLUDE FORMULA, JUICE, SOLID FOODS.
How old was Sample Person when {he/she} was first fed something other than breastmilk or water? INCLUDE FORMULA, JUICE, SOLID FOODS. ENTER UNIT
How old was Sample Person when {he/she} completely stopped breastfeeding or being fed breast milk?
How old was Sample Person when {he/she} completely stopped breastfeeding or being fed breast milk?
How old was Sample Person when {he/she} completely stopped breastfeeding or being fed breast milk? ENTER UNIT

protocol.preferredDefinition: These interviewer-administered questions ascertain whether an infant was breastfed, the duration of breastfeeding, and the introduction of solid foods.
